title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act titled "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007" includes a section on the short title and another section on the establishment of the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of amounts from charitable donations or program authorizations. Funds can be used for advertising and administration expenses, with limits set on the percentage and total amount that can be spent each fiscal year. The National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 allows the Administrator to use up to $200,000 annually for administering prize competitions. Any remaining funds can be used for prizes awarded under the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury can invest excess funds in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 allows the Administrator to use funds for administering prize competitions and awards. Obligations can be acquired on original issue or by purchase, and sold at market price. Interest and proceeds from obligations held in the Fund are credited to it. NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. Members serve staggered three-year terms. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered three-year terms, with initial terms staggered for continuity. Vacancies are filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term. Members cannot serve for more than 6 years and receive no compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered three-year terms, with vacancies filled by the Administrator. Members are not compensated but reimbursed for travel expenses. The Committee meets at least 4 times a year, with NASA officers present to provide guidance. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A sponsor is a person approved to participate in the program. The Administrator will select a logo for sponsors based on Advisory Committee recommendations. To apply as a sponsor, a person must submit an application with required information to the Administrator. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allows individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. To apply as a sponsor, a person must submit an application with the amount to be contributed and a description of the promotional program they plan to develop. This program should focus on promoting educational programs in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allows individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. Approved applicants must enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator, providing a specified amount and using the logo in their promotional program. Restrictions include not placing logos on spacecraft. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program prohibits logos on spacecraft, astronaut endorsements, agency-wide endorsements, in-kind contributions, contributions below a minimum amount, and any other features deemed inappropriate by the Administrator. Procedures will be established to protect proprietary information, and Congress has issued a statement regarding NASA participation. The Administrator will establish procedures to protect proprietary information. Congress encourages NASA to participate in activities authorized by the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. Unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo may result in civil action and penalties. The Administrator may take civil action for violations, including injunctions and penalties of $100,000 per violation. Unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo may also result in civil action. The Administrator must report actions taken annually to Congress, detailing receipts and expenditures. The Advisory Committee must report annually to Congress on all actions taken by NASA, including receipts, expenditures, and evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Committee consults with directors of various NASA Centers for program improvement ideas. SEC. 5 of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 is amended to include the NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007. SEC. 6 defines terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
